{{ja-kanjitab|sort=となかい|yomi=irr}}

{{borrowing|ja|ain|sort=となかい}}<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref><ref name="SMK5">{{R:Shinmeikai5}}</ref>, either {{m|ain|トナッカイ|tr=tonakkai|pos=recorded as Sakhalin dialect}},<ref name="SMK5">{{R:Shinmeikai5}}</ref><ref name="Batchelor">{{cite-book

}}</ref> or {{m|ain|トゥナㇵカィ|tr=tunahkay|pos=listed in contemporary Ainu sources}}.<ref name="IntAin">{{cite-book

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|じゅん|ろく|yomi=o}}

From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=しゅんろく'}} compound {{m|zh|馴鹿|tr=zwin luwk|lit=docile + deer}}.  Compare modern {{etyl|yue|-}} readings ''seon<sup>4</sup> luk<sup>6</sup>'', ''seon<sup>4</sup> luk<sup>6-2</sup>'', and {{etyl|cmn|-}} ''xùnlù'', ''xúnlù''.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=goon|じゅんろく|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|じゅんろく}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=しゅんろく'|uncommon}} a [[reindeer]]

=====Usage notes=====
''Tonakai'' (above) is the more common reading for this term.
